response.answer_text: The Roman Empire left much of S-E Europe latin speaking, including today’s Romania (which back then was called Dacia, one of the most colonized and militarized provinces)  However, many populations which used to be latin speaking became slavicised/magyarized as result of various migrations from the North and from Asia. Romanians avoided this fate because the migrants were trying to reach the very prosperous byzantine lands and not the poor proto-romanian inhabited ones (we see the same phenomenon today when masses of asian/african migrants pass through numerous countries, without settling there, because they’re aiming to reach the rich N-W Europe), because the territory with later became romanian (and where proto-romanians lived) was extremely inhospitable (80% of the territory was dense forest, besides having really steep mountains and marshes), while the byzantine lands were quite hospitable, and because the proto-romanians were abandoned by the roman army early on and exposed to progressively worse and worse in terms of barbarians while the balkan latins mostly suffered shock exposures and didn’t survive. In conclusion, romanians didn’t come from anywhere, they formed as a people in the area where they now live (From an admixture of thracian speaking natives and roman colonists and soldiers). The aromanians are a slightly different story. These /Vlachs/ are, in fact, the so-called Dacians, also called Bessians. Earlier they lived in the vicinity of the Danube and Saos, a river which we now call Sava, where the Serbians live today, and /later/ withdrew to their inaccessible fortifications. (...) And these left the region: some of them were dispersed to Epirus and Macedonia, and a large number established themselves in Hellas.  —Kekaumenos: Strategikon The few historical, written accounts we have suggest they migrated from the North, coincidentally around the period when the magyars stormed the area (10th century). Linguistics also support that such a split did occur about a millennia ago, exactly what the historical sources claim.

I want to specify that this answer is not related only to the language spoken. It involves genetic results. Hence the so called Latin element is not as much present in the actual population genes. Latin is the language, but the ancestry is mostly Thraco-Geto-Dacian for all these people that now speak a Latin based language. They are similar to Bulgarians, Serbians and Hungarians as well, considering the genetic heritage. Vlach, Wallach, or Olah, is a name that foreigners and migrators gave to the ancient, local latin speaking population, when they made contact. Generally speaking, Vlachs are spread all over Balkan peninsula: Bulgaria, Greece, Serbia, Croatia, etc. and of course Romania. All Latin speakers in the region are called Vlachs. They speak either Romanian, or Macedo-Romanian (Aromanian), Megleno-Romanian, or Istro-Romanian. Romanians, as the population is named today, come from Romania. How surprising for some (!?). Geto-Dacians lived in Romania for at least 5000 years and they are the most prominent genetic ancestors of today’s Romanian population. Look at a genetic map of the country and see. Haplogroups I2, R1a, R1b, E1b1b, J2 and some G are all ancient genes. I2 is a split from I which came to Europe 50,000 years ago as first Homo Sapiens on the continent. E1b1b is North African as origin but present in Europe for 10,000. J2 is also very old in Europe (mostly South). R1a and R1b are Indo-Europen speakers that came to Caucasus 6500 years ago (Kurgan migration). All these ancient genes are present today in Romanian population on an over 95% proportion. And it was like that for at least 5000 years. Aromanians speak a dialect of Romanian, could be classified as a separate language, but really close, as they can understand each other better than other Romance languages. Aromanians are Macedonians (Northern Greece) who started to speak a latin language. Macedonians are a transition people from Daco-Thracians to Greeks proper, genetically speaking. Search any genetic map of the Balkans and see by the area. For more detailed explanation: DNA of the majority ethnic group in Romania and Moldova

My theory is a bit different - dealing with the defeat of Carpi, Dacian tribe relocated by Constantine the Great around 318 in Thracia, with other emperors after him doing the same thing. Since all the land was possessed by people living in that area, the only solution for them was to become shepherds. Since they were already exposed to Latin language, their Latinization was similar to the Dacians and they ended speaking very similar; however, due to the switch of official language from Latin to Greek, there are differences - for example, Aromanians say ”prota oară” - first time, proto- first in the Greek language, while Romanians say ”prima oară”, using the Latin term prima. This is a proof that Romanians did not migrate from South, or all would use these Greek expressions. With the Slavic migrations taking the lands, the proto-Romanians were not affected, since they lived in mountain areas of no real interest for the Slavic tribes. With the second Bulgarian Kingdom, they were involved in fighting against Byzantines and Latins(Crusaders); due to the ethnic affiliation of the rulers, it was natural that the Bulgarian Kingdom extend to the Northern Danubian areas populated by Romanians. When the Bulgarians took over the rule, the two populations separated, with Romanians on the Northern bank of the Danube, and the Bulgarians on the Southern. Latin and subsequent dialects derived from it kept in contact and evolved in close contact. Danube proved to be the only barrier latter on, determining the differences between the Southern dialects and Romanian language.

Romanians and Aromanians are the Romance-speaking heirs of the Roman citizens of the Eastern Roman Empire. When nomad Slavs occupied Dacian lands, Vlachs/Romanians had to run into the forests and mountains. Soon Avars, Slavs and Turkic Bulgars left Northern Danubian lands including Dacia and occupied by force Balkans. It was a happy moment for Romanians who finally managed to assimilate the rest of nomad people of Dacia. But Slavs arrival became a disaster for Vlachs/Aromanians of Balkans who had to see how migrators made states on their lands. Aromanians had to run into forests and mountains because of pagan Slavs ferocity. After Slavs’ Christianization, Aromanians had to attend Slavic churches and a lot of them were Slavicized. The most known case of Slavicization is in Bosnia, where Vlachs/Aromanians were the majority. Frequenting Slavic churches they got Slavic names and became bilingual, and finally they were considered Serbians or Croats or Bosnians. Aromanians are the autochtonous people of Balkans and they live or lived in all Balkan states.
